DOCNAME: CASE OF ANDRIA OY AND KARI KARANKO v. FINLAND
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , an owner of the applicant company , was born in DATE and lives in LOC .

CARDINAL . NORP Since DATE S. had ordered children ’s clothing from the then PERSON ( apparently not the same company as the applicant company , and since DATE called “ PERSON ” ) . In DATE the then PERSON debt collecting operation was transferred to a company E.

CARDINAL . On DATE , PERSON , which is not an applicant before this ORG , filed a writ of summons ( case no . CARDINAL ) against PERSON with ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätten ) . The plaintiff PERSON was represented by the second applicant . The plaintiff requested outstanding payment of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( FAC ) with interest for an order of children ’s clothing made by S.
CARDINAL . On DATE , the summons was served on the defendant , who contested the claims , alleging that he had cancelled the order in time .

CARDINAL . The court held a preparatory hearing on DATE , in which the plaintiff PERSON was represented by the second applicant . According to the Government , the plaintiff had stated that it would file a supplementary writ of summons and a claim for damages . On DATE PERSON ’s representative NORP and the court agreed by telephone that the supplementary claims were to be submitted by CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . DATE ORG informed the plaintiff PERSON that a preparatory hearing would be held in DATE and reminded that it had not lodged a supplementary summons .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant company filed a new writ of summons against S. with ORG ( case no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . This claim also concerned the recovery of an outstanding payment of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( ORG CARDINAL ) for the purchase of goods . The applicant company also claimed damages in the amount of ORG CARDINAL ( ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) . The summons was served on the defendant on DATE , who submitted his response on DATE .
CARDINAL . Meanwhile , the preparatory hearing concerning the first writ of summons , filed by PERSON , scheduled for CARDINAL DATE , was cancelled .
CARDINAL . ORG considered it appropriate to examine all the claims together . According to the Government , on DATE it joined the actions and served the defendant ’s responses on the plaintiffs .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE , the court held preparatory hearings . The main hearing was held on DATE , at which CARDINAL witness was heard . The court also examined CARDINAL items of written evidence . At the hearing , the applicant company submitted a further claim for damages of FIM CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( EUR CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court issued a joint judgment in the CARDINAL cases . Without giving reasons , PERSON was no longer considered as a plaintiff and the applicant company was indicated as the only plaintiff . The court rejected all the claims and ordered the applicant company , together with the second applicant , to pay the defendant ’s legal expenses . It found that the second applicant , being the plaintiff ’s legal representative , had negligently caused PERSON to incur legal costs . In its judgment it also noted the following :

“ It was not possible for ORG to eliminate entirely the lack of clarity in the claims of the parties , especially those of the plaintiff , and the grounds of and evidence for these claims . ... It has examined the case to the extent that the parties have presented their claims and the grounds for them , and what had been the matter in question in ORG view . ”

CARDINAL . PERSON and the applicants appealed to ORG , stressing , inter alia , that PERSON had issued the first writ of summons . The appellate court upheld the judgment on DATE , without holding an oral hearing . It considered , as ORG , that the applicant company was the only plaintiff in the proceedings and consequently dismissed PERSON ’s appeal .
CARDINAL . According to the applicants , PERSON transferred the allegedly outstanding account from PERSON to the applicant company on DATE .

CARDINAL . E. and the applicants sought leave to appeal and appealed to ORG ( korkein oikeus , högsta domstolen ) , complaining , inter alia , about the length of the proceedings . They also alleged that both PERSON and the applicant company had lodged summonses and , consequently , the CARDINAL ORG claims should not have been examined together . They further stated :
“ [ The applicant company ] has been a party to the proceedings only as of DATE when it filed a writ of summons with ORG ( summons no . PERSON ) , by which it requested damages from [ S. ] ... ”
CARDINAL . ORG refused leave to appeal on DATE .
